huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: In the past this unit was a split unit, and the last few years it has been managed as a harvest objective.  There is great access to cut tracks and run hounds.  The main roads receive the most hunting pressure.  I wouldn't wait to long in the winter, because snow levels can keep certain roads in accessible.  There are several cougar hunting guides to use if you don't have your own hounds.  There are several hunters who choose to pursue and not kill which can make it difficult for hunters with kill tags.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

The Book Cliffs mountain range is one of the more remote areas in Utah.  There are no service stations for many miles.  Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, and snow.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Most hunters prefer to cut tracks early in the morning. Hunters must be present when the hounds are turned loose. Cougars are very solitary animals and can be very difficult to find. Make sure you are checking the quota for this unit before you go out hunting. Once the quota is filled the unit is closed. Be sure to familiarize yourself with the cougar guide book before you start hunting.

Here are some major drainage's where hunters have had success in the past: Atchee Ridge, Rainbow, Evacuation, Three Mile, Big Park, Cooper Cyn, McCook Ridge, Monument Ridge, Sweet Water, Rail Road Cyn, Indian Ridge, Seep Ridge, Winter Ridge, Willow Creek, Wood Cyn, and Buck Cyn.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Permit holders may hunt any open harvest objective season. Before you begin a hunting trip to a harvest objective unit, you must visit the Cougar Harvest Objective Page to verify that a unit is still open. The website will be updated each day by noon MST. Updates become effective the following day, 30 minutes before official sunrise. Effective for the 2021-22 season, there will no longer be a phone line available to check for open units.
huntMaster.NOTES: This unit is under a predator management plan for Mule Deer.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Required: Any harvested cougar must be checked by a DWR employee within 48 hours of the date of kill. The DWR employee will affix a permanent possession tag to the pelt or unskinned carcass. You may not possess an unskinned carcass or green pelt after the 48 hour check-in period. If you need to reach a Division employee after regular business hours, over a weekend, or on a holiday, contact your local police dispatch. In addition, you cannot ship a green pelt out of the state of Utah or present it to a taxidermist if the pelt does not have a permanent possession tag attached.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas.  There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program (http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/).
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: :  Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, Willow Creek, and Little Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days.
DWR WMA’S:  There is a 14 day limit on WMA’s, and there is no camping on the Willow Creek WMA.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS:
There are several access points to the Book Cliffs.  From the north side there are two main roads that take you to the Book Cliffs.  Utah State Road 88 located between Vernal and Roosevelt.  As you follow it south it turns into the Seep Ridge Road.  Hwy 45 or the Bonanza Hwy is located east of Vernal.  It takes you towards the east side of the Book Cliffs.  After you cross the White River you come to the Dragon or Duck Rock intersection.  The Dragon Rd will take you south to the Book Cliffs.

The Hay Canyon Rd is the main access road on the south side of the Book Cliffs.  You can access it from I-70.  It is a hard packed dirt/gravel road.  

The roadless area has two access points, a north and a south.  The north access is called the Ten Mile Knoll trailhead.  It is located at the start of Steer Ridge.  There is a parking area, but it can fill up in a hurry with trucks and horse trailers.  The south trailhead starts at the top of Sego Canyon.  The road starts at Thompson Springs in Grand County and continues up the Sego Canyon Rd; follow it to the end of the road.  There is a water trough at the trailhead, but it is not always full of water.  This trailhead can also fill up with vehicles, and trailers.  There are no bathrooms or other facilities at either of these trailheads, so plan accordingly.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA.  The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.   

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.  

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape.  There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them.  Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access.  There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads.  The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.  

There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs.  The Kings Well Rd starts at the Seep Ridge Rd on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Rd on the east side.  The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Rd and goes through the bottom of Sweet Water, top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek, and to Big Park.  It is a great road to locate cougars during this time of year.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.  

There are some private ranches that post their property.  There are also privately owned lands that allow access through the DWR Walk-in-Access Program.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties—Boundary begins at Thompson Canyon road and I-70 at Thompson; north on this road to Sego Canyon Road; north along this road to the Ute Indian Reservation boundary; west along this boundary to the Green River; northeast along the Green River to the White River; east along the White River to the Utah-Colorado state line; south along this state line to I-70; southwest along I-70 to Thompson Canyon road at Thompson. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Moab, Seep Ridge, Vernal, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453, or the Price office, 435-613-3700.
